issueDTO.title: FFI Iterator
issueDTO.description: Iterating across the FFI boundary is extremely slow, so it was initially determined to not be included. However, it may be necessary for some coreth API functionality (as well as being generally helpful for testing). This could still be implemented relatively simply by amortizing the FFI calls to batch the key-value pairs to relatively few calls. This will still require some clever memory management to avoid copying too much data (idea: allocate a pool in Go?) and to enable 2D arrays in C to be translated into slices of slices in Go. Additionally, freeing the iterator may be difficult if using a literal Rust iterator.

summary.main: Iterating across the FFI boundary is extremely slow, so it was initially determined to not be included. However, it may be necessary for some coreth API functionality (as well as being generally helpful for testing). The issue requires clever memory management to avoid copying too much data and to enable 2D arrays in C to be translated into slices of slices in Go.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the FFI Iterator to iterate across the FFI boundary efficiently, without significant performance degradation. The iterator should be able to handle batched key-value pairs and enable 2D arrays in C to be translated into slices of slices in Go.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by amortizing FFI calls to batch key-value pairs to relatively few calls, allocating a pool in Go to avoid copying too much data, and enabling 2D arrays in C to be translated into slices of slices in Go. Additionally, freeing the iterator may be difficult if using a literal Rust iterator.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'good first issue', indicating it's a suitable task for a contributor to tackle. The issue description provides some ideas for implementing the FFI Iterator, including amortizing FFI calls, clever memory management, and translating 2D arrays in C to slices of slices in Go.

issueDTO.title: Feature request: watch filesystem changes
issueDTO.description:
Aider can detect file system changes and use hints for agentic work: https://aider.chat/docs/usage/watch.html

This provides immediate integration for all not-currently supported IDEs. E.g. leaving a comment in a file and saving it will give `q` a prompt to action.
comments:
+1 This is happening to me a lot. My workflow is often:
1. I let Q CLI make changes to a file
2. I manually make a small tweak to a file outside of Q CLI
3. I ask Q CLI to make another change to the file

The CLI doesn't re-read the file at step #3 and just uses the file contents it already has in the conversation history. It often writes over my changes in step #2.

repository.description: ✨ Agentic chat experience in your terminal. Build applications using natural language.
repository.name: amazon-q-developer-cli

summary.main: Aider can detect file system changes and use hints for agentic work, providing immediate integration for all not-currently supported IDEs. This will enable users to make changes to files outside of the CLI and have the CLI re-read the file contents and use the changes accordingly.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the feature to be implemented in a way that allows Aider to detect file system changes and use hints for agentic work, ensuring that the CLI re-reads the file contents after changes are made outside of the conversation history.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by modifying the code to detect file system changes and update the conversation history accordingly. This may involve using file system monitoring libraries or APIs to monitor changes to files.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is labeled as 'good first issue', indicating it's a suitable issue for a contributor to tackle. The issue is about implementing feature request: watch filesystem changes, which will allow Aider to detect file system changes and use hints for agentic work.

issueDTO.title: Update declares and gets to use new declare_or_get_param API
issueDTO.description:
The new `nav2_ros_common` package has a `declare_or_get_param` API from @MarcoMatteoBassa that we should use instead of the usual pattern we have for `declare_parameter_if_not_declared` and then `get_parameter`. That way we declare if not declared and return the value all on a single line. 

This should become a member of the `nav2::LifecycleNode` and we can use it from the `node->declare_or_get_param` or as standalone `nav2::declare_or_get_param` when given a `NodeT` or parameters interface. 

Also consider other parameter APIs like `get_parameter_or`, raw `declare_parameter`'s / `get_parameters`'s, `declareParameter`'s and others. Audit configurations.
comments: I'd like to handle this 😃
Ok, please! That would be much appreciated!
Perfect! I'll get started with it 💪

repository.name: navigation2

summary.main: The issue is about updating the `nav2_ros_common` package to use the new `declare_or_get_param` API, which is available from @MarcoMatteoBassa. This change aims to simplify the declaration and retrieval of parameters by using a single API instead of the current pattern.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the `nav2_ros_common` package to use the new `declare_or_get_param` API instead of the usual pattern for declaring and getting parameters. This change should ensure a single line declaration and retrieval of parameters, making the code more efficient and readable.

This change should be made in the `nav2::LifecycleNode` and also considered for other parameter APIs like `get_parameter_or`, `declare_parameter`'s, and `get_parameters`'s.

issueDTO.title: [Feature] Make Infinistore Link Type Configurable
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Infinistore supports Ethernet and Infiniband, but LMCache hard-codes the link type to Ethernet when setting up its Infinistore connection. This limits the usefulness of the Infinistore backend.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would like to add a configuration parameter (maybe `infinistore_link` or `infinistore_link_type`) that allows choosing Ethernet or Infiniband at runtime.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Currently I work around this by editing the hard-coded link type value. This is not a great solution for folks who are not building from source.

**Additional context**
I am happy to make this change if maintainers agree it should be made.

repository.description: Supercharge Your LLM with the Fastest KV Cache Layer
repository.name: LMCache

summary.main: The Infinistore link type is currently hardcoded to Ethernet in LMCache, limiting its usefulness. A configuration parameter is needed to make the link type configurable at runtime.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for LMCache to support configuring the link type (Ethernet or Infiniband) at runtime, allowing users to choose the appropriate link type for their setup.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by adding a configuration parameter (e.g., `infinistore_link` or `infinistore_link_type`) that allows choosing Ethernet or Infiniband at runtime.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is labeled as 'good first issue', indicating it's a suitable task for a contributor to tackle.
